an7.63:1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
an7.63:1.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the householder Anāthapiṇḍika, where he sat on the seat spread out.

an7.63:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena anāthapiṇḍikassa gahapatissa nivesane manussā uccāsaddā mahāsaddā honti.
an7.63:1.2.eng: Now at that time people in Anāthapiṇḍika’s home were making a colossal racket.

an7.63:1.3.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an7.63:1.3.eng: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

an7.63:2.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu te, gahapati, nivesane manussā uccāsaddā mahāsaddā kevaṭṭā maññe macchavilope”ti?
an7.63:2.1.eng: “Householder, what’s with the people making that colossal racket in your home? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”

an7.63:2.2.eng: “Sir, that’s my daughter-in-law Sujātā. She’s been brought here from a wealthy family.

an7.63:2.3.pli: Sā neva sassuṃ ādiyati, na sasuraṃ ādiyati, na sāmikaṃ ādiyati, bhagavantampi na sakkaroti na garuṃ karoti na māneti na pūjetī”ti.
an7.63:2.3.eng: She doesn’t obey her mother-in-law or father-in-law or her husband. And she does not honor, respect, esteem, and venerate the Buddha.”

an7.63:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sujātaṃ gharasuṇhaṃ āmantesi:
an7.63:3.1.eng: Then the Buddha addressed Sujātā, saying,

an7.63:3.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho sujātā gharasuṇhā bhagavato paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho sujātaṃ gharasuṇhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an7.63:3.3.eng: “Yes, sir,” she replied. She went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to her:

an7.63:4.1.eng: “Sujātā, a man can have seven kinds of wife.

an7.63:4.3.pli: Vadhakasamā, corīsamā, ayyasamā, mātāsamā, bhaginīsamā, sakhīsamā, dāsīsamā.
an7.63:4.3.eng: A wife like a killer, a wife like a thief, a wife like a lord, a wife like a mother, a wife like a sister, a wife like a comrade, and a wife like a bondservant.

an7.63:4.4.pli: Imā kho, sujāte, satta purisassa bhariyāyo.
an7.63:4.4.eng: These are the kinds of wife that a man can have.

an7.63:4.5.eng: Which one of these are you?”

an7.63:4.6.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ, bhante, imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
an7.63:4.6.eng: “Sir, I don’t understand the detailed meaning of what the Buddha has said in brief.

an7.63:4.7.pli: Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā tathā dhammaṃ desetu yathāhaṃ imassa bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ jāneyyan”ti.
an7.63:4.7.eng: Please teach me this matter so I can understand the detailed meaning.”

an7.63:4.8.pli: “Tena hi, sujāte, suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
an7.63:4.8.eng: “Well then, Sujātā, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an7.63:4.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho sujātā gharasuṇhā bhagavato paccassosi.

an7.63:5.1.eng: “With a mind full of hate and no kindness,

an7.63:5.2.eng: lusting for others, looking down on her husband,

an7.63:5.3.eng: she longs to murder him who paid the price for her.

an7.63:5.4.eng: A man’s wife of this sort

an7.63:5.5.eng: is called a wife and a killer.

an7.63:6.1.eng: A woman’s husband earns his wealth

an7.63:6.2.eng: by focusing on a profession, trade, or farming.

an7.63:6.3.eng: And even if it’s only a little, she wants to take it.

an7.63:6.4.eng: A man’s wife of this sort

an7.63:6.5.eng: is called a wife and a thief.

an7.63:7.1.eng: She’s an idle glutton who doesn’t want to work.

an7.63:7.2.eng: Her words are harsh, fierce, and rude.

an7.63:7.3.eng: He works hard, but she lives as his master.

an7.63:7.4.eng: A man’s wife of this sort

an7.63:7.5.eng: is called a wife and a lord.

an7.63:8.2.eng: looking after her husband like a mother her child.

an7.63:8.3.eng: She keeps the wealth that he has earned secure.

an7.63:8.4.eng: A man’s wife of this sort

an7.63:8.5.eng: is called a wife and a mother.

an7.63:9.2.eng: as a younger sister respects her elder.

an7.63:9.3.eng: Conscientious, she does what her husband says.

an7.63:9.4.eng: A man’s wife of this sort

an7.63:9.5.eng: is called a wife and a sister.

an7.63:10.2.eng: like one reunited with a long-lost comrade.

an7.63:10.3.eng: She’s of good pedigree, virtuous, and devoted.

an7.63:10.4.eng: A man’s wife of this sort

an7.63:10.5.eng: is called a wife and a comrade.

an7.63:11.1.eng: She has no anger <j>when threatened with violence by the rod.

an7.63:11.3.eng: she withstands her husband and does what he says.

an7.63:11.4.eng: A man’s wife of this sort

an7.63:11.5.eng: is called a wife and a bondservant.

an7.63:12.1.eng: The kinds of wives here called

an7.63:12.3.eng: immoral, harsh, and lacking regard for others,

an7.63:12.4.eng: when their body breaks up they set course for hell.

an7.63:13.1.eng: But the kinds of wives here called

an7.63:13.3.eng: steadfast in their own morality, <j>restrained for a long time,

an7.63:13.4.eng: when their body breaks up <j>they set course for a good place.

an7.63:14.1.pli: Imā kho, sujāte, satta purisassa bhariyāyo.
an7.63:14.1.eng: Sujātā, these are the seven kinds of wife that a man can have.

an7.63:14.2.eng: Which one of these are you?”

an7.63:14.3.pli: “Ajjatagge maṃ, bhante, bhagavā dāsīsamaṃ sāmikassa bhariyaṃ dhāretū”ti.
an7.63:14.3.eng: “Sir, from this day forth may the Buddha remember me as a wife like a bondservant.”

an7.64:1.1.pli: “Sattime, bhikkhave, dhammā sapattakantā sapattakaraṇā kodhanaṃ āgacchanti itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā.
an7.64:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these seven things that please and assist an enemy happen to an irritable woman or man.

an7.64:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa evaṃ icchati:
an7.64:1.3.eng: Firstly, an enemy wishes for an enemy:

an7.64:1.6.pli: Na, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa vaṇṇavatāya nandati.
an7.64:1.6.eng: Because an enemy doesn’t like to have a beautiful enemy.

an7.64:1.7.pli: Kodhanoyaṃ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalo kodhābhibhūto kodhapareto, kiñcāpi so hoti sunhāto suvilitto kappitakesamassu odātavatthavasano;
an7.64:1.7.eng: An irritable individual, overcome and overwhelmed by anger, is ugly, even though they’re nicely bathed and anointed, with hair and beard dressed, and wearing white clothes.

an7.64:1.8.pli: atha kho so dubbaṇṇova hoti kodhābhibhūto.

an7.64:1.9.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo dhammo sapattakanto sapattakaraṇo kodhanaṃ āgacchati itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā.
an7.64:1.9.eng: This is the first thing that pleases and assists an enemy which happens to an irritable woman or man.

an7.64:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa evaṃ icchati:
an7.64:2.1.eng: Furthermore, an enemy wishes for an enemy:

an7.64:2.4.pli: Na, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa sukhaseyyāya nandati.
an7.64:2.4.eng: Because an enemy doesn’t like to have an enemy who sleeps at ease.

an7.64:2.5.pli: Kodhanoyaṃ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalo kodhābhibhūto kodhapareto, kiñcāpi so pallaṅke seti gonakatthate paṭalikatthate kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇe sauttaracchade ubhatolohitakūpadhāne;
an7.64:2.5.eng: An irritable individual, overcome and overwhelmed by anger, sleeps badly, even though they sleep on a couch spread with woolen covers—shag-piled, pure white, or embroidered with flowers—and spread with a fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red pillows at both ends.

an7.64:2.6.pli: atha kho so dukkhaññeva seti kodhābhibhūto.

an7.64:2.7.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo dhammo sapattakanto sapattakaraṇo kodhanaṃ āgacchati itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā.

an7.64:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa evaṃ icchati:
an7.64:3.1.eng: Furthermore, an enemy wishes for an enemy:

an7.64:3.2.eng: ‘If only their needs are not amply satisfied!’

an7.64:3.4.pli: Na, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa pacuratthatāya nandati.
an7.64:3.4.eng: Because an enemy doesn’t like to have an enemy whose needs are amply satisfied.

an7.64:3.5.pli: Kodhanoyaṃ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalo kodhābhibhūto kodhapareto, anatthampi gahetvā ‘attho me gahito’ti maññati, atthampi gahetvā ‘anattho me gahito’ti maññati.
an7.64:3.5.eng: When an irritable individual, overcome and overwhelmed by anger, gets what they don’t need they think, ‘I’ve got what I need.’ When they get what they need they think, ‘I’ve got what I don’t need.’

an7.64:3.6.pli: Tassime dhammā aññamaññaṃ vipaccanīkā gahitā dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattanti kodhābhibhūtassa.
an7.64:3.6.eng: When an angry person gets these things that are the exact opposite of what they need, it’s for their lasting harm and suffering.

an7.64:3.7.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo dhammo sapattakanto sapattakaraṇo kodhanaṃ āgacchati itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā.

an7.64:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa evaṃ icchati:
an7.64:4.1.eng: Furthermore, an enemy wishes for an enemy:

an7.64:4.4.pli: Na, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa bhogavatāya nandati.
an7.64:4.4.eng: Because an enemy doesn’t like to have an enemy who is wealthy.

an7.64:4.5.pli: Kodhanassa, bhikkhave, purisapuggalassa kodhābhibhūtassa kodhaparetassa, yepissa te honti bhogā uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatā bāhābalaparicitā sedāvakkhittā dhammikā dhammaladdhā, tepi rājāno rājakosaṃ pavesenti kodhābhibhūtassa.
an7.64:4.5.eng: When an individual is irritable, overcome and overwhelmed by anger, the rulers seize the legitimate wealth they’ve earned by their efforts, built up with their own hands, gathered by the sweat of their brow.

an7.64:4.6.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho dhammo sapattakanto sapattakaraṇo kodhanaṃ āgacchati itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā.

an7.64:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa evaṃ icchati:
an7.64:5.1.eng: Furthermore, an enemy wishes for an enemy:

an7.64:5.4.pli: Na, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa yasavatāya nandati.
an7.64:5.4.eng: Because an enemy doesn’t like to have a famous enemy.

an7.64:5.5.pli: Kodhanoyaṃ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalo kodhābhibhūto kodhapareto, yopissa so hoti yaso appamādādhigato, tamhāpi dhaṃsati kodhābhibhūto.
an7.64:5.5.eng: When an individual is irritable, overcome and overwhelmed by anger, any fame they have acquired by diligence falls to dust.

an7.64:5.6.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcamo dhammo sapattakanto sapattakaraṇo kodhanaṃ āgacchati itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā.

an7.64:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa evaṃ icchati:
an7.64:6.1.eng: Furthermore, an enemy wishes for an enemy:

an7.64:6.4.pli: Na, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa mittavatāya nandati.
an7.64:6.4.eng: Because an enemy doesn’t like to have an enemy with friends.

an7.64:6.5.pli: Kodhanaṃ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalaṃ kodhābhibhūtaṃ kodhaparetaṃ, yepissa te honti mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā, tepi ārakā parivajjanti kodhābhibhūtaṃ.
an7.64:6.5.eng: When an individual is irritable, overcome and overwhelmed by anger, their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin avoid them from afar.

an7.64:6.6.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, chaṭṭho dhammo sapattakanto sapattakaraṇo kodhanaṃ āgacchati itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā.

an7.64:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa evaṃ icchati:
an7.64:7.1.eng: Furthermore, an enemy wishes for an enemy:

an7.64:7.2.pli: ‘aho vatāyaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyyā’ti.
an7.64:7.2.eng: ‘If only, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell!’

an7.64:7.4.pli: Na, bhikkhave, sapatto sapattassa sugatigamane nandati.
an7.64:7.4.eng: Because an enemy doesn’t like to have an enemy who goes to a good place.

an7.64:7.5.pli: Kodhanoyaṃ, bhikkhave, purisapuggalo kodhābhibhūto kodhapareto kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
an7.64:7.5.eng: When an individual is irritable, overcome and overwhelmed by anger, they do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

an7.64:7.7.pli: kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati kodhābhibhūto.
an7.64:7.7.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an7.64:7.8.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, sattamo dhammo sapattakanto sapattakaraṇo kodhanaṃ āgacchati itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā.
an7.64:7.8.eng: This is the seventh thing that pleases and assists an enemy which happens to an irritable woman or man.

an7.64:8.1.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, satta dhammā sapattakantā sapattakaraṇā kodhanaṃ āgacchanti itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vāti.
an7.64:8.1.eng: These are the seven things that please and assist an enemy which happen to an irritable woman or man.

an7.64:9.3.eng: When they get what they need,

an7.64:9.4.eng: they take it to be what they don’t need.

an7.64:13.1.eng: An angry person doesn’t know the good.

an7.64:13.2.eng: An angry person doesn’t see the truth.

an7.64:13.3.eng: When a person is beset by anger,

an7.64:14.1.eng: An angry person destroys with ease

an7.64:14.3.eng: Afterwards, when the anger is spent,

an7.64:14.4.eng: they’re tormented as if burnt by fire.

an7.64:15.3.eng: And when their anger flares up,

an7.64:16.1.eng: They have no conscience or prudence,

an7.64:17.1.eng: The deeds that torment a man

an7.64:17.2.eng: are far from those that are good.

an7.64:17.4.eng: listen to this, for it is the truth.

an7.64:18.1.eng: An angry person slays their father;

an7.64:18.3.eng: An angry person slays a saint;

an7.64:18.4.eng: a normal person, too, they slay.

an7.64:19.1.eng: A man is raised by his mother,

an7.64:19.3.eng: But an angry ordinary person slays

an7.64:19.4.eng: even that good woman who gave him life.

an7.64:20.3.eng: But when angered, they kill themselves in different ways,

an7.64:21.4.eng: or fling themselves down a mountain gorge.

an7.64:22.1.eng: When they commit deeds of killing babes

an7.64:22.3.eng: they don’t realize what they do,

an7.64:22.4.eng: for anger leads to their downfall.

an7.64:23.1.eng: The snare of death in the form of anger

an7.64:23.3.eng: You should cut it out by self-control,

an7.64:23.4.eng: by wisdom, energy, and right ideas.

an7.64:24.1.eng: An astute person should cut out

an7.64:24.3.eng: And they’d train in the teaching in just the same way,

an7.64:25.1.eng: Free of anger, free of despair,

an7.64:25.2.eng: free of greed, with no more longing,

an7.645-1124:1.26.eng: these seven things should be developed.”

an7.645-1124:2.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

an7.645-1124:2.2.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
an7.645-1124:2.2.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

an7.645-1124:2.4.eng: The Book of the Sevens is finished.

an7.65:1.1.pli: “Hirottappe, bhikkhave, asati hirottappavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti indriyasaṃvaro;
an7.65:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when there is no conscience and prudence, one who lacks conscience and prudence has destroyed a vital condition for sense restraint.

an7.65:1.2.pli: indriyasaṃvare asati indriyasaṃvaravipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti sīlaṃ;
an7.65:1.2.eng: When there is no sense restraint, one who lacks sense restraint has destroyed a vital condition for ethical conduct.

an7.65:1.3.pli: sīle asati sīlavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti sammāsamādhi;
an7.65:1.3.eng: When there is no ethical conduct, one who lacks ethics has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.

an7.65:1.4.pli: sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an7.65:1.4.eng: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an7.65:1.5.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an7.65:1.5.eng: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an7.65:1.6.pli: nibbidāvirāge asati nibbidāvirāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an7.65:1.6.eng: When there is no disillusionment and dispassion, one who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an7.65:1.7.eng: Suppose there was a tree that lacked branches and foliage.

an7.65:1.8.pli: Tassa papaṭikāpi na pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi pheggupi sāropi na pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an7.65:1.8.eng: Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would not grow to fullness.

an7.65:1.9.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, hirottappe asati hirottappavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti indriyasaṃvaro;
an7.65:1.9.eng: In the same way, when there is no conscience and prudence, a person who lacks conscience and prudence has destroyed a vital condition for sense restraint.

an7.65:1.10.pli: indriyasaṃvare asati indriyasaṃvaravipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti sīlaṃ;
an7.65:1.10.eng: When there is no sense restraint, one who lacks sense restraint has destroyed a vital condition for ethical conduct.

an7.65:1.11.pli: sīle asati sīlavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti sammāsamādhi;
an7.65:1.11.eng: When there is no ethical conduct, one who lacks ethics has destroyed a vital condition for right immersion.

an7.65:1.12.pli: sammāsamādhimhi asati sammāsamādhivipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an7.65:1.12.eng: When there is no right immersion, one who lacks right immersion has destroyed a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an7.65:1.13.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane asati yathābhūtañāṇadassanavipannassa hatūpaniso hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an7.65:1.13.eng: When there is no true knowledge and vision, one who lacks true knowledge and vision has destroyed a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an7.65:1.14.pli: nibbidāvirāge asati nibbidāvirāgavipannassa hatūpanisaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an7.65:1.14.eng: When there is no disillusionment and dispassion, one who lacks disillusionment and dispassion has destroyed a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an7.65:2.1.pli: Hirottappe, bhikkhave, sati hirottappasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti indriyasaṃvaro;
an7.65:2.1.eng: When there is conscience and prudence, a person who has fulfilled conscience and prudence has fulfilled a vital condition for sense restraint.

an7.65:2.2.pli: indriyasaṃvare sati indriyasaṃvarasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti sīlaṃ;
an7.65:2.2.eng: When there is sense restraint, one who has fulfilled sense restraint has fulfilled a vital condition for ethical conduct.

an7.65:2.3.pli: sīle sati sīlasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti sammāsamādhi;
an7.65:2.3.eng: When there is ethical conduct, one who has fulfilled ethical conduct has fulfilled a vital condition for right immersion.

an7.65:2.4.pli: sammāsamādhimhi sati sammāsamādhisampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ;
an7.65:2.4.eng: When there is right immersion, one who has fulfilled right immersion has fulfilled a vital condition for true knowledge and vision.

an7.65:2.5.pli: yathābhūtañāṇadassane sati yathābhūtañāṇadassanasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti nibbidāvirāgo;
an7.65:2.5.eng: When there is true knowledge and vision, one who has fulfilled true knowledge and vision has fulfilled a vital condition for disillusionment and dispassion.

an7.65:2.6.pli: nibbidāvirāge sati nibbidāvirāgasampannassa upanisasampannaṃ hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ.
an7.65:2.6.eng: When there is disillusionment and dispassion, one who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.

an7.65:2.7.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rukkho sākhāpalāsasampanno. Tassa papaṭikāpi pāripūriṃ gacchati, tacopi pheggupi sāropi pāripūriṃ gacchati.
an7.65:2.7.eng: Suppose there was a tree that was complete with branches and foliage. Its shoots, bark, softwood, and heartwood would grow to fullness.

an7.65:2.8.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, hirottappe sati hirottappasampannassa upanisasampanno hoti …pe…
an7.65:2.8.eng: In the same way, when there is conscience and prudence, one who has fulfilled conscience and prudence has fulfilled a vital condition for sense restraint. …

an7.65:2.9.eng: One who has fulfilled disillusionment and dispassion has fulfilled a vital condition for knowledge and vision of freedom.”
